instruction: How does the accuracy of machine learning models with kernel principal component analysis (KPCA) dimension reduction compare to those without in estimating the contents of organic matter (OM), iron (Fe), and zinc (Zn) in black soil using hyperspectral technology?
Output: The accuracy of machine learning models with kernel principal component analysis (KPCA) dimension reduction is higher compared to those without in estimating the contents of organic matter (OM), iron (Fe), and zinc (Zn) in black soil using hyperspectral technology. The results of the study show that the determination coefficients and residual prediction deviation for the prediction samples of the KPCA-RF model are higher than those of the RF model for estimating soil OM content. Similarly, the accuracy of the KPCA-RF model for estimating soil Fe and Zn contents is also higher. The same trend is observed for the KPCA-SVM model. Therefore, the machine learning models combined with KPCA are more promising and effective in the quantitative inversion of soil composition contents.
